page.title: 13Local History - Hittisleigh
page.content: On a map dated 1300 the village was shown as Whithornleigh. There is some controversy about the derivation of the name Hittisleigh, meaning either "a Tenant's Pasture", or "Hope", "Joy" or "Pleasure" in a clearing in a wood. It is in the church that most evidence has been preserved and is easily available to see. The church of St Andrew is simple and charming, the nave and chancel dating from 14th century. The north aisle was added c.1500, and has a fern patterned beam along one side. A identically carved beam can be seen in Medlake Farm. The loss of agricultural labourers and tied cottages, and influx of a wealthier population has led to the restoration of cottages and buildings, many of which are listed as historically and architecturaly important.
